channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Beginning. Here’s What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: A Carnival of Life Flourishes in Kabul’s Field of the Dead
item.media:description: The Kart-e-Sakhi cemetery in Kabul. After decades of war, more and more Afghan families have some reason to visit Kabul’s cemeteries, where an ever-larger slice of everyday life is now centered.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: At the Kart-e-Sakhi cemetery, children hustle for tips, young lovers seek privacy, a cotton-candy seller circulates and cockfights are held every weekend.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: After Car Crash, U.S. Prohibits Its Sailors in Japan From Drinking
item.media:description: A bar frequented by American military personnel on the Japanese island of Okinawa.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The roughly 19,000 Navy personnel in the country were also confined to their bases after a sailor thought to have been inebriated was involved in a car accident.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Greed, Corruption and Danger: A Tarnished Afghan Gem Trade
item.media:description: An Afghan businessman checked lapis lazuli at his shop in Kabul in March. Afghanistan has long been one of the chief sources of lapis lazuli, a prized gemstone associated with love and purity.
item.description: The government’s muted response to a militia’s takeover of a giant lapis mine suggests an aligning of interests among insurgents and the political elite.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Aging Japanese Women Find a Resigned Solace in South Korea
item.media:description: Chiyo Yagi, 90, in her room at Nazarewon, a nursing home for elderly Japanese women, in Gyeongju, South Korea. “Korea is a better place for me to live because I at least have a daughter here,” Ms. Yagi said, “My daughter comes to see me once a year.”
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: As their numbers dwindle, the residents of Nazarewon, a South Korean nursing home for Japanese women, are reminders of the combative history between the neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Pedro Kuczynski Holds Thin Lead Over Keiko Fujimori in Peru Presidential Election
item.media:description: Peruvian citizens in Santiago, Chile, voted on Sunday in an election between Pedro Pablo Kuczynski and Keiko Fujimori.
item.description: Mr. Kuczynski, a former prime minister, held a narrow advantage over Ms. Fujimori, the daughter of a former president, as officials said they would keep counting votes.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Report Accuses Mexico of Crimes Against Humanity in Drug War
item.media:description: Jorge Parral Gutiérrez and Alicia Rabadán Sánchez at their home in Cuernavaca, Mexico. Jorge Antonio Parral Rabadán, their son, was kidnapped by a criminal gang and then killed by soldiers in a raid in 2010.
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: A study by the Open Society Justice Initiative concluded that indiscriminate force — killings, forced disappearances and torture — and impunity are a part of state policy.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Kalashnikov, Maker of AK-47, Looks to Rebrand
item.media:description: In Gorky Park in Moscow on the Victory Day holiday, Kalashnikov showed off the company’s weapons and its new logos. This couple was given a souvenir photograph.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: After American sanctions cut off one of its biggest markets, the Russian gun maker embarked on changes that executives say are yielding results.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: European Union Seeks U.N. Approval to Intercept Libya-Bound Arms
item.media:description: Forces loyal to Libya’s United Nations-backed unity government in front of a power plant captured from the Islamic State near Sirte last week.
item.description: Europe wants permission to expand an existing naval operation’s mandate from intercepting migrant boats leaving Libya to blocking weapons heading in.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Iraqis Who Flee Fighting in Falluja Find Hardship and Hunger
item.description: Survivors reach aid camps hungry, thirsty and scared, and their ordeals are not over: They are in the arms of a government without the resources to care for them.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Arrest Made in Killing of Jordanian Intelligence Officers
item.description: Five people were killed in the assault in a Palestinian refugee camp near the capital, Amman. The government called it a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Kenya’s Collective ‘Uh, Oh’: Another Election Is Coming
item.media:description: A motorcyclist stopped at a burning barricade set up by opposition supporters in the Kibera slum of Nairobi, Kenya, during the weekly protest on what is now known as Tear Gas Monday.
item.description: The contest for president is next year, but protests and violence have already begun. A 5-year-old was shot on Monday, and demonstrations are hurting the economy.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Confusion in a Romanian Village as 3 Vasile Cepois Run for Mayor
item.description: The citizens of Draguseni, Romania, were presented with a predicament on Sunday when they had to decide who should lead their village.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Italy’s Five Star Movement Leads in Rome’s Mayoral Election
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, the Five Star Movement’s candidate for mayor of Rome, at a fund-raising event in May. She received 35.3 percent of the vote in the first round over the weekend.
item.description: A victory for the movement’s candidate, Virginia Raggi, in a runoff in two weeks would be a blow to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, whose Democratic Party struggled in the first round.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Louvre and Musée d’Orsay Prepare to Reopen as Floodwaters Recede in Paris
item.media:description: Tourists in Paris on Friday walked past empty line markers outside the Louvre Museum, which was closed because of flooding on Seine River.
item.description: The museums closed their doors and moved tens of thousands of artworks to higher floors last week as a precaution against the rain-swollen Seine River.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Joachim Gauck, German President, Won’t Seek Second Term
item.description: Even though the office is largely ceremonial, the announcement could create more problems for Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Bucharest Journal: At Ceausescu’s Villa, Focus Is on Décor, Not Dictatorship
item.media:description: The living room at the Palatul Primaverii, or Spring Palace, where Nicolae Ceausescu lived with his wife, Elena. Visitors are asked to put on plastic shoe coverings before entering the villa.
item.description: The mansion where Nicolae Ceausescu lived with his wife, Elena, during the 24 years he ruled Romania was shrouded in secrecy. It is now a museum.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Ukraine Struggles to Shake Off Legacy of Corruption
item.media:description: Aivaras Abromavicius, the Ukrainian former minister of economy and trade, in Brussels in December 2014.
item.description: The resignation of Aivaras Abromavicius, the economy and trade minister, amid allegations of cronyism was a worrying sign in the fight against graft.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere: Wu Tong on Traversing Musical Boundaries in China
item.media:description: Wu Tong performing on his sheng, a traditional Chinese wind instrument, at the Tianqiao Theater in Beijing on New Year’s Eve.
item.description: Mr. Wu, one of China’s most successful crossover musicians, discusses his new album and what it was like to be a rock musician in China in the ’90s.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Branded a ‘Terrorist’ for Reporting Two Sides of Ukraine’s War
item.media:description: Pro-Russian rebels in Horlivka, in eastern Ukraine, launched missiles at Ukrainian troops on February 2015.
item.description: A journalist has had guns pointed at him, slept in a shipping container, and walked past corpses, but until now had never been listed as a terrorist by a nationalist website.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: 3 Dead, 10 Hospitalized as 1 Belgian Train Runs Into Another
item.description: A passenger train slammed at high speed into a slow-moving freight train in eastern Belgium, killing three people and sending 10 others to the hospital, authorities said Monday. The accident came just hours after reported lightning strikes and a signal disruption on the line.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In a Reversal, Germany’s Military Growth Is Met With Western Relief
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the German defense minister, visited troops during a training exercise in southern Germany in March.
item.description: As Europe faces pressure from ISIS and a more muscular Russia, Germany has pledged to bolster its military, reversing its decades-long instinctive pacifism.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: White House Letter: President Obama and India’s Modi Forge an Unlikely Friendship
item.media:description: President Obama and Prime Minister Narendra Modi in the gardens of Hyderabad House in New Delhi in 2015.
item.description: There are few relationships between President Obama and another world leader more unlikely than the one he has with Prime Minister Narendra Modi given their political differences.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: NPR Journalist and Translator Killed by Taliban in Afghanistan
item.media:description: David Gilkey in 2010 in the Arghandab Valley.
item.description: Mr. Gilkey was the first civilian American journalist killed in Afghanistan during the 15-year-long Afghan conflict.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Russia to Return Israeli Tank Used in ’82 Battle With Syrians
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Jerusalem in 2012.
item.description: The episode, during a battle with Syrian forces in southern Lebanon, left three Israeli soldiers missing and has haunted Israel for more than 30 years.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Guaranteed Income for All? Switzerland’s Voters Say No Thanks
item.media:description: A referendum on a guaranteed income was rejected by 77 percent of Swiss voters on Sunday. Supporters of the initiative, including Kim-Fabian von Dall’Armi, gathered in Basel to celebrate the fact that 23 percent voted yes.
item.description: A proposal to give each adult the equivalent of about $2,560, regardless of employment status, was rejected 77 percent to 23 percent.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: U.S. to Press China to Curb Industrial Output
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew, speaking on Sunday at Tsinghua University in Beijing.
item.description: “Excess capacity is not just a domestic issue,” Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew said ahead of the two nations’ Strategic and Economic Dialogue.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Panama Papers Show How Rich United States Clients Hid Millions Abroad
item.media:description: Panama City, Panama, home to the law firm Mossack Fonseca. A trove of the firm’s internal documents, known as the Panama Papers, have shaken the financial world.
item.description: Mossack Fonseca, the Panamanian law firm at the center of the trove of revealing documents, offered a menu of services to conceal the true owners.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LIPTON and JULIE CRESWELL

item.title: Taliban Claim Killing of 7 in Afghan Province, Including New Attorney General
item.description: An attack at a court in Logar on Sunday was revenge for recent executions of Taliban prisoners, a spokesman for the insurgents said.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Wife of Bangladesh Policeman Who Went After Islamist Militants Is Killed
item.media:description: A relative consoling the children of Mahmuda Khanam Mitu, who was killed in an attack in Chittagong, Bangladesh, on Sunday.
item.description: An attack in Chittagong on Sunday followed a number of others targeting religious minorities, intellectuals and secularist writers.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Researchers Uncover a Flaw in Europe’s Tough Privacy Rules
item.description: Computer scientists were able to discover the names of roughly a third of the people who had asked that online links about themselves be taken down.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: What in the World: Hong Kong’s Murder Mystery: Who Is Poisoning the Dogs?
item.media:description: An older sign on Bowen Road, a popular dog-walking path, cautioned owners to be vigilant.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Over 200 dogs may have been poisoned since the 1980s, but officials do not know who is responsible or what the motives may be.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

item.title: What in the World: When West Africans Dress, the Fabric Is the Message
item.media:description: The designs on wax print fabric worn by West African women can be very personal.
item.description: The bold patterns and images on wax print cotton cloth that many women wear may celebrate pop culture, religion, politics or social mores.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: In Istanbul’s Taxis, Buckling Up Is an Insult
item.description: What’s the matter, don’t you trust my driving? You must be from out of town. (And, please, pay no attention to the speedometer.)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Only in Europe Can Britain Be Great
item.description: There’s nothing glorious about isolation. True patriotism shows in voting for a positive role within the European Union.
item.dc:creator: GORDON BROWN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Right Way to Observe Ramadan
item.description: Fasting during the Islamic holy month should be a choice, not a compulsion.
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Editorial: Brazil’s Gold Medal for Corruption
item.media:description: Michel Temer, Brazil’s interim president, at an inauguration ceremony for the minister of transparency on Thursday.
item.description: To earn the trust of his countrymen, the interim president needs to take meaningful steps against corruption.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
